title: Quiz 2: Community Health Nursing - January 2024 FQE
description: Complete Final Qualifying Examination from January 2024 covering Immunization, Health Promotion, Epidemiology, and Management.

questions.question: The dose, site and route of administration for intramuscular pneumococcal vaccine is:
questions.explanation: Under the KEPI schedule, PCV10 (Pneumococcal) is administered as 0.5 ml via Intramuscular (IM) injection on the Right Thigh. Pentavalent is given on the Left Thigh.
questions.hint: Think about the thigh opposite to where Pentavalent is given.

questions.question: Baby Q, born at home is brought to the clinic for immunization 3 weeks after birth. The antigens to be given to Baby Q on this first visit include:
questions.explanation: At birth (or first contact if missed), a baby receives BCG and OPV Zero. At 3 weeks, the baby is not yet eligible for the 6-week vaccines (Penta 1, OPV 1), so they catch up on birth doses.
questions.hint: Which vaccines are due at birth?

questions.question: The health status is greatly affected and determined by which of the following:
questions.explanation: Socio-economic factors (income, education, housing) have the greatest aggregate impact on health status, often outweighing individual behavioral choices.
questions.hint: Think about the social determinants of health.

questions.question: Fast cold chain option is recommended when there is:

options.text: Need to transport vaccines from regional stores to sub county stores
Distance between levels of health systems is long
Vaccine distribution system is expensive and unreliable

questions.explanation: Fast cold chain strategies are used to bypass unreliable systems or storage levels to ensure potency is maintained.
questions.hint: Used when the standard system fails.

questions.question: The following Covid-19 vaccines are categorized as mRNA (messenger Ribonucleic Acid) vaccines:
questions.explanation: Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech are mRNA vaccines. AstraZeneca and J&J are viral vector vaccines. Sinopharm is inactivated.
questions.hint: The vaccines primarily used in the US.

questions.question: During a census, the de jure population refers to:

options.text: All people actually present in a given area at a given time
Total population of adults aged 18 years and above
People who belong to a given area at a given time by virtue of legal or usual residence
Total estimate of the people not present at home during the night of the census

questions.explanation: De jure counts people based on their usual/legal residence. De facto counts people where they are physically present.

questions.question: The principle of equity in PHC means:

options.text: Health services made universally accessible to individuals
Health services equally distributed according to population data
Health services provided at a cost the community can afford always
Providing health services based on the needs of the population

questions.explanation: Equity means fairness; providing more to those who need more to ensure equal outcomes, rather than just equal distribution.

questions.question: Total fertility rate refers to:

options.text: The average number of children that would be born to a married woman
The child bearing capacity of a woman
The number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year
The number of live births per 1000 married women in reproductive age group in a given year

questions.explanation: Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the average number of children a woman would have in her lifetime if current fertility rates persisted. Option A is the closest conceptual fit provided.
questions.hint: Average number of children per woman.

questions.question: There are six (6) life cycle cohorts in KEPH. As a community health nurse, what services will you address in cohort 3?

options.text: School health programme, nutritional care, prevention of injuries
Substance abuse counselling, prevention of non-communicable diseases, nutritional care
Sexually transmitted diseases counselling, family planning, prevention of injuries

questions.explanation: Cohort 3 is Late Childhood (6-12 years). Key services are School Health, Nutrition, and Hygiene. Cohort 4 is Adolescents.

questions.question: Arrange the steps in community entry for community strategy in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: Sequence: Awareness -> Analysis -> Planning -> Systems.
questions.hint: You must enter/sensitize before you can analyze or plan.

questions.question: Monitoring in management refers to:

options.text: The analysis of the effectiveness and direction of an activity
The timing and frequency of observations
The systematic, regular collection and occasional analysis of information
The amount of time and resources put into the project relative to the outputs and outcomes

questions.explanation: Monitoring is the continuous, systematic process of collecting data to track progress. Evaluation (A) is periodic analysis of effectiveness.

questions.question: In Community strategy, members of the community health committee that you would utilize would include:

options.text: Community Health Volunteers, Community Health Assistants

questions.explanation: CHCs are composed of community representatives and the Facility In-Charge (Technical Advisor).
questions.hint: Community reps and the facility head.

questions.question: Water related diseases includes:
questions.explanation: Water-related diseases involve vectors that breed or live in water (Mosquitoes/Malaria, Blackfly/Onchocerciasis, Snails/Schisto).

questions.question: Use of Pit latrine is the most important disposal method of feacal matter in rural areas.
questions.explanation: The pit latrine remains the primary and most accessible method of excreta disposal in rural Kenya.

questions.question: Biological criteria in determining features of good housing includes:

options.text: Presence of good water supply, good methods of refuse disposal
Well-designed kitchen, Presence of adequate light
Adequate facilities for washing utensils, Free from air pollution
Free from air pollution, Adequate rooms for privacy

questions.explanation: Biological needs relate to preventing disease transmission. Safe water and refuse disposal prevent biological agents (pathogens/vectors).

questions.question: You have been invited as a member of a key project geared towards promoting community health. Which key components of physical environment will you give in your presentation?
questions.explanation: The physical environment includes natural elements like air, water (rivers), soil (land), and climate.

questions.question: Strategic plans are key in every organization and refer to:

options.text: Broad plans developed to handle recurring and relatively routine situations
Broad plans developed to handle non-programmed events and emergencies
Broad plans developed by top managers outlining the rules governing the organization
Broad plans developed by top managers to guide the general direction of the organization

questions.explanation: Strategic planning focuses on the long-term vision and general direction of an organization.

questions.question: You have made a decision to provide Pre exposure prophylaxis to a client. This decision is related to:

options.text: Accidental exposure to HIV and they are HIV positive
Individuals who have been raped and are HIV negative
People who are involved in accidents and are HIV positive
Individuals at high risk of getting HIV and are HIV negative

questions.explanation: PrEP is for HIV-negative people at substantial risk. Rape/Accidents require PEP (Post-Exposure).

questions.question: People living with HIV/AIDS get opportunistic infection because:

options.text: The drug used to treat HIV cause infections
It is natural for people with AIDS to get opportunistic infection
HIV weakens the immunity and makes it difficult to fight disease
The HIV gets into the body and mutates into disease causing agents

questions.explanation: HIV destroys CD4 cells, compromising the immune system and allowing opportunistic infections to thrive.

questions.question: Health promotion is a concept in health that:

options.text: Is concerned with older people's health
Increases control over determinants of health

questions.explanation: Health promotion enables people to increase control over and improve their health (Ottawa Charter).

questions.question: Primary prevention on health promotion includes:
questions.explanation: Primary prevention prevents disease onset (Immunization, Diet). Screening is Secondary prevention.

questions.question: In a debate of centralization and decentralization, which of the following would you highlight as advantages of centralization:

options.text: High cost effectiveness, no duplication of efforts
No duplication of efforts, quicker and better decision making
High cost effectiveness, increased freedom and flexibility
Increased freedom and flexibility of staff, no duplication of efforts

questions.explanation: Centralization ensures uniformity and avoids duplication, improving cost effectiveness.

questions.question: Which advantages of intra uterine contraceptive device (IUCD) would you highlight in a health talk?

options.text: Highly effective, offers long term protection, prevents ectopic pregnancy
Highly effective, pelvic examination not required, protects endometrial cancer
Offers long term protection, requires pelvic examination prevent ovulation
Easy to use, highly effective, decreases benefits of breast cancer

questions.explanation: IUCDs are highly effective, long-acting, and reduce the absolute risk of all pregnancies (including ectopic).

questions.question: Which strategy can you employ to motivate youths to access reproductive health services?

options.text: Encouraged them to come in groups for the family planning services
Advocate for correct condom use trainings
Advocate for creation and sustainability of youth friendly services by service providers
Advise provision of services to them without questioning their intention

questions.explanation: Youth Friendly Services (YFS) address barriers like fear of judgment and lack of privacy.

questions.question: The correct statement about the emergency contraceptive pills is that they can be:

options.text: Taken within 5 days of unprotected intercourse
Used in replacement for regular oral contraception
Spontaneous abortion causing agents once taken after implantation
Containing the estrogen hormone in their main content

questions.explanation: ECPs (like Ulipristal) can be effective up to 5 days (120 hours). They prevent ovulation.

questions.question: High fiber diet in a diabetic client is recommended because it:

options.text: Quickens digestion but slows glucose absorption
Prolongs digestion and reduces absorption of glucose
Maintains good nutritional status and normal weight

questions.explanation: Soluble fiber slows digestion and glucose absorption, preventing blood sugar spikes.

questions.question: When giving a nutrition health talk to mothers, you would advise them to report infants whose weight is not doubling at which age:
questions.explanation: An infant should double their birth weight by 6 months.

questions.question: The type of environment where developmental projects are given priority in a community is:
questions.explanation: The political environment determines priority setting and resource allocation.

questions.question: Internationally notifiable diseases include:
questions.explanation: Plague, Yellow Fever, and Cholera are the classic quarantinable diseases.

questions.question: Diseases that are acquired via fecal oral route include:
questions.explanation: Polio, Giardia, and food poisoning (ingestion) are transmitted via the fecal-oral/ingestion route.

questions.question: Trachoma infection progresses in sequence. Characteristics of second stage infection include:

options.text: Formation of scars, eyelids turn inwards
Presence of follicles, tinny blood vessels crowd at cornea
Eye lids turn inwards, presence of tiny blood vessels
Whitish scars crowd conjunctiva, eye lids turn outwards

questions.explanation: The active inflammatory stages (TF/TI) involve follicles and inflammation. Scarring (TS) is a later stage.

questions.question: Clinical features of pertussis (whooping cough) include:
questions.explanation: Paroxysmal cough, post-tussive vomiting, and cyanosis are classic features of severe pertussis.

questions.question: An immunizable disease that occurs in sporadic manner is:
questions.explanation: Tetanus is not contagious and occurs sporadically from environmental exposure (soil/injury).

questions.question: The most common type of viral hepatitis is:
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A is extremely common globally, often causing asymptomatic infections in childhood.

questions.question: The period that starts when the body defense mechanism has been overpowered by the agent is:
questions.explanation: When defenses are overpowered and signs appear, the disease crosses the clinical horizon into the Early Disease stage.

questions.question: Prevention and control measures of typhoid fever through attacking the source involves:

options.text: Vaccination of those at risk, Mass treatment
Maintain hygiene, Vaccination of those at risk

questions.explanation: Attacking the source means treating the infected person (reservoir). Notification leads to case finding and treatment.

questions.question: Some of the difficulties encountered during community diagnosis include:

options.text: Observation variation, standardization of test items, sampling methods
Sampling methods, presentation of results, observation variation
Selection of interviewers, observation variation, test items that are used
Standardization of test items, data collection methods, observation variation

questions.explanation: Sampling bias, observer variation, and instrument validity are common research challenges.

questions.question: When conducting community diagnosis, the best time to collect data is:

options.text: When the sample population is available
When you have willing and available assistants
During public holiday when people are at home
When resources needed to analyze the data are available

questions.explanation: To get representative data, you must collect it when respondents are present.

questions.question: The short-term implications related to female genital mutilation include:
questions.explanation: Immediate complications include severe pain and hemorrhage.

questions.question: Gender sensitivity refers to:

options.text: Lack of interaction between women and men
Unfair treatment of men and women
Socially determined cultural practices of men and women

questions.explanation: Gender sensitivity is the ability to perceive and understand gender issues and inequalities.

questions.question: Select the characteristics of communicable diseases: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Communicable diseases are characterized by infectivity, pathogenicity, virulence, and transmissibility.

questions.question: Strategies to reduce stigma among people living with HIV/AIDS include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Strategies involve education, empowerment, leadership involvement, and integrating services.

questions.question: Which concepts of Community Health Nursing are applicable in a region with scarce resources? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PHC concepts like prevention, participation, and collaboration maximize limited resources.

questions.question: Identify traditional family planning methods used before modern contraceptives: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Traditional methods include withdrawal, breastfeeding (LAM), abstinence, and cultural practices (herbs).

questions.question: Select the major interventions applied in the pre-paralytic stage of poliomyelitis: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Rest is crucial to prevent severe paralysis. Supportive care and notification are also key.

questions.question: Strategies utilized in facilitating community action include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Action is facilitated through dialogue, organization (committees), training, and resources.

questions.question: Steps to prevent program errors related to Adverse Events Following Immunization (AEFI) include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Preventing errors requires sterile technique, correct reconstitution, and proper cold chain.

questions.question: Interventions to reduce malnutrition among children in low income settlements include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Key interventions are education, growth monitoring, supplements, and micronutrients.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the decision-making process in the correct order:
questions.explanation: The logical process is: Define -> Analyze -> Generate -> Select -> Implement -> Evaluate.
